label: thm-mean-field-equation
title: The Mean-Field Equations for the Euclidean Gas
nl_statement: The evolution of the Euclidean Gas in the mean-field limit is governed by a coupled system describing the alive density $f(t,z)$ and the dead mass $m_d(t)$.

equations.label: eq-mean-field-pde-main
equations.latex: \partial_t f = L^\dagger f - c(z)f + B[f, m_d] + S[f]

\partial_t f(t,z) = -
abla\cdot(A(z) f(t,z)) + 
abla\cdot(\mathsf{D}
abla f(t,z)) - c(z)f(t,z) + \lambda_{	ext{revive}} m_d(t)  rac{f(t,z)}{m_a(t)} + S[f](t,z)

conclusion.text: The evolution of the Euclidean Gas in the mean-field limit is governed by a coupled system of equations for the alive density $f(t,z)$ and the dead mass $m_d(t)$.

constraints: zero in interior, positive near boundary

label: thm-mass-conservation
title: Total Mass Conservation and Population Dynamics
nl_statement: Any sufficiently regular solution $(f(t,z), m_d(t))$ to the Mean-Field Equations conserves total population mass and satisfies a specific evolution equation for the alive population mass.

hypotheses.text: $(f(t,z), m_d(t))$ is a sufficiently regular solution to the Mean-Field Equations.

conclusion.text: The total population mass $m_a(t) + m_d(t)$ is conserved for all $t>0$, and the alive mass evolves according to $\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}m_a(t) = \lambda_{\text{rev}} m_d(t) - k_{\text{killed}}[f](t)$.

variables.role: density of alive population at time t in state z
dead population mass at time t
alive population mass at time t
rate of killing dependent on alive population density

implicit_assumptions.text: The Mean-Field Equations provide a well-defined system whose solutions $(f, m_d)$ exist and are sufficiently regular.

label: thm-killing-rate-consistency
title: Consistency of the Interior Killing Rate Approximation
nl_statement: Under specified regularity assumptions, the discrete exit rate converges pointwise to a smooth killing rate function $c(x,v)$, and the expected discrete killing fraction converges uniformly to the continuous killing rate $K_{\text{continuous}}$.

hypotheses.text: Assumption regarding density regularity for killing

conclusion.text: There exists a smooth killing rate function $c \in C^\infty_c(\Omega)$ with compact support in $\mathcal{T}_\delta$ such that $\lim_{\tau \to 0} \frac{1}{\tau} p_{\text{exit}}(x,v,\tau) = c(x,v)$ pointwise, and $\lim_{\tau \to 0} \frac{1}{\tau} K_{\text{discrete}}(\tau) = K_{\text{continuous}}$ with the specified error bound.

variables.role: solution to the dynamics after time \tau
expected killing fraction in discrete timestep

implicit_assumptions.text: The domain $\Omega$ and the set $X_{\text{valid}}$ are well-defined geometric structures, likely related to the domain boundary.
The dynamics $x^+(\tau; x,v)$ are defined by the underlying kinetic equation (implied by context of convergence).
The term $\delta$ defines a boundary layer region $\mathcal{T}_\delta$ near the boundary.

label: thm-mean-field-limit-informal
title: Mean-Field Limit (Informal Statement)
nl_statement: The empirical density $f_N^\tau(t, x, v)$ of the $N$-particle discrete Fragile Gas dynamics converges weakly to a limiting density $f(t, x, v)$ as $N \to \infty$ and $\tau \to 0$ under the condition $\tau = O(N^{-\alpha})$ for some $\alpha > 0$.

equations.latex: f_N^\tau(t, x, v) := \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N \delta(x - X_i^\tau(t), v - V_i^\tau(t))

hypotheses.text: $(X_i^\tau(t), V_i^\tau(t))_{i=1}^N$ be the $N$-particle discrete Fragile Gas dynamics with timestep $\tau$.
The limit is taken in $N \to \infty, \tau \to 0$ with $\tau = O(N^{-\alpha})$ for $\alpha > 0$.

conclusion.text: The empirical density converges weakly to $f(t, \cdot, \cdot)$.

variables.role: particles of the $N$-particle discrete Fragile Gas dynamics
